channel.title: posts on charlieegan3
channel.description: Recent content in posts on charlieegan3

item.title: Week Notes: 4
item.description: I’ve been making small steps towards being able to do dev work on a cloud instance. This week’s small steps have been: Adding a GCE builder for my dev-machine project.

item.title: Week Notes: 3
item.description: At work this week I’ve spent much of my time writing and responding to feedback on technical design proposals for features I’m working on. This is not something that I’ve done in a big way before so I’m enjoying learning something new and getting feedback on them.

item.title: Fun things I’m doing with GitHub Actions
item.description: Two years ago, GitHub announced Actions, their repo-integrated, workflow automation product. It took me ages to get access, then when I finally did, it seemed to get a bit of a bad review for being rough around the edges.

item.title: Week Notes: 2
item.description: Over the course of the bank holiday I moved my personal websites from my Raspberry Pi Kubernetes cluster to Netlify. I’m enjoying using GitHub actions and am pleased to have these running somewhere I don’t need to worry about them.

item.title: Teaching Rego to compare Semantic Versions
item.description: This is a post about a recent contribution I made to the OPA project. OPA (Open Policy Agent) aims to provide a standard means of authorization in the form of a policy server with a domain specific language called Rego.

item.title: Week Notes: 1
item.description: This week after work I’ve been doing a bit of side project house keeping. I’ve mostly been automating backups of my Notion and Dropbox data using GitHub actions.

item.title: Building a contact list in Notion that works for me
item.description: Earlier this week I found myself migrating my contact list to Notion. I decided to do this because I was lacking the following features in Outlook to effectively manage my contacts:

item.title: SemVer comparisons with OPA
item.description: Update: I’ve written a follow up post here explaining how I later added this functionality to Rego itself. I recently found myself faced with the task of writing OPA policies that involved comparing Semantic Versions.

item.title: Introducing charlieegan3/infrastructure
item.description: Since starting at Jetstack I’ve spent much time building a personal Kubernetes cluster to run my various side projects. I no longer run anything on Heroku, Lamdba, App Engine or Netlify.

item.title: Fun things I did in Rego while validating Christmas Trees
item.description: I’ve been working on fun project recently for the ‘Christmas Show & Tell’ event at the London Computation Club. At club show and tells there are imaginary points available for matching the theme.

item.title: What to do with all these cluster updates...
item.description: This year at work I’ve been building out a platform on Google’s managed Kubernetes offering GKE. While GKE makes it easier to automate the provisioning and management of clusters - managing updates of anything more than a handful of clusters can quickly becomes painful without the right tools.

item.title: Refunding my faulty Macbook with another EU consumer law claim
item.description: I recently got a faulty 2016 12” Macbook refunded by making an EU consumer law claim. I’ve done this once before in 2016; now more familiar with the process I thought I’d write up round two.

item.title: 'Please feel free to use a toilet' & other things I liked about Japan
item.description: I went to Japan last month. As we walked around I found myself enjoying the little differences more than anything else. Since returning, I’ve found myself talking about them a lot and thought it’d make for quite a good alternative write up of the trip.

item.title: How a simple admission webhook lead to a cluster outage
item.description: Jetstack often works with customers to provision multi-tenant platforms on Kubernetes. Sometimes special requirements arise that we cannot control with stock Kubernetes configuration. In order to implement such requirements, we’ve recently started making use of the Open Policy Agent project as an admission controller to enforce custom policies.

item.title: Introducing our best-practice GKE Terraform module
item.description: Jetstack works with many customers using Google Cloud’s Kubernetes Engine. We work closely with teams to configure their clusters to conform with best practises.

item.title: Running a cheap GKE cluster: Revisted
item.description: Last year I wrote a post about how I run my personal cluster in a cost-effective way on GKE. I’ve since been able to automate the main manual step and thought I’d post a short update.

item.title: Tracking all the plays or how I learned to stop worrying and build my own Last.fm
item.description: For my latest side project I built a tool to better track the music I listen to. I now have a single BigQuery table with my play history from Spotify, Youtube, Soundcloud and Shazam.

item.title: Introducing Jetstack's Kubernetes for Application Developers Course
item.description: Jetstack’s current course offering is largely aimed at those in an operational role - deploying and managing clusters. With this new course, we’re introducing a new ‘track’ for a developer audience.

item.title: Running a wiki with Gollum on Kubernetes
item.description: I’ve long been searching for a good, self-hosted, personal wiki. I went as far to build my own with client-side encryption running on Heroku as a Rails app.

item.title: Running a cheap GKE cluster with public ingress & zero load balancers
item.description: Update: I’ve posted about a small refinement here. Joining Jetstack earlier this year finally convinced me that I needed a side-project cluster. All the cool kids had one and I wanted one too.

item.title: Bringing Photoshop image-stacking to mobile with FFmpeg, Hugin, ImageMagick & Hyper.sh
item.description: Update You can try the project here. Code available here. Update 2 I have taken down the live demo - there are now many apps that make this easy on phones.

item.title: I made an interactive portfolio site with Hugo
item.description: My last post explained about how I create backups of my Instagram posts. I had a few people ask about why this was useful. Other than the Instagram doomsday-scenario, in it’s current form (a git repo with some images and JSON metadata) it wasn’t.

item.title: Backing up Instagram
item.description: I enjoy using Instagram to share my photos. The restricted feature-set; public-by-default; similarities to Twitter & (original) square format constraint all appeal. Last year I completed a #365photochallenge on Instagram.

item.title: Welcome to Android
item.description: For a series of reasons I recently bought a Google Pixel 2. I’ve been wanting a change of scene and to go back to Android for some time - so far it’s going well.

item.title: Back in the side-project groove
item.description: Since starting work full-time I’ve been lacking the energy and time for side projects. Recently I’ve had a few free weekends and have completed initial versions of two new projects.

item.title: Terraform adventures: Deploy a serverless microservice ~2 mins
item.description: terraform destroy has been a game changer for my public cloud toy projects. Building up a reproduceable config that can brought straight back the next time you come to work on the project is invaluable.

item.title: Terraform adventures: Host a static website ~5 minutes
item.description: I was in the market for a project to spend some more time with Terraform when I saw this prompt in the AWS console. Terraform can do all those things & I have a static site (this site) that I could use to test it out.

item.title: 500 kilometres of electric-car, west-coast exploring
item.description: I’ve been working on char.gy for the last few months. I fear it may be becoming all consuming as I felt compelled to write up our EV centric holiday…

item.title: Running ActionCable behind Elastic Load Balancers on AWS
item.description: We were recently tasked with adding a feature that showed the status of a IoT device as it changed. It was important that the status page updated quickly; and given we’d recently upgraded to Rails 5, this was a prime opportunity to learn ActionCable.

item.title: Fixing up my vimrc
item.description: After working closely with a proficient vim user on a summer internship; I started experimenting with vim during the summer of 2015. I made the usual mistakes of copying the other’s vimrcs and installing too many plugins - I think everyone has to go though that phase though.

item.title: How this website (currently) works
item.description: While charlieegan3.com has been my ‘online home’, my personal site has gone through various revisions. Personal websites are subject to an above average level of tinkering and experimentation.

item.title: Deploying indigo-falcon to production!
item.description: On the Bookmetrix project we used a different process for managing our releases in git. We took feature branches from master and opened pull requests with a ‘release branch’ as the base.

item.title: Phasing out my laptop setup script
item.description: TL;DR - I switched from a complicated script that personalised my development laptop to a setup minimal enough to make it irrelevant. I’ve used an Mac as my main computer since 2005, in 2005 I was 11 years old.

item.title: Heroku Deploy button treasure hunt with GitHub and BigQuery
item.description: Sometime last year I listened to a Changelog podcast episode about the GitHub data that’s been made available on BigQuery, Google’s tool for querying large datasets.

item.title: A Weekend with The Google Cloud Platform
item.description: For some time I’ve been looking to consolidate my ‘side project infrastructure’. I have two projects running Digital Ocean droplets (serializer.io and standpoint); json-charlieegan3 runs on hyper.

item.title: NEXT London 2016 - Google Cloud Platform's User Conference
item.description: Paula and I attended last Friday’s NEXT London 2016 - Google Cloud Platform’s User Conference - the largest Google developer and IT gathering in the UK, exploring the latest developments in cloud technology.

item.title: TIL at Container Camp
item.description: I was lucky enough to get today off and attend Container Camp. Still relatively new to containers I had a lot to learn, here are some of the most important things I took away from the day.

item.title: Development Re-bundling in Dockerland
item.description: When starting out development on a Dockerized application, adjusting Dockerfiles and rebuilding images is a common task. Bringing together two separate services, as well as applying some gem security patches, we found ourselves doing this a lot.

item.title: Things I like about Rust
item.description: I’ve recently completed my first useful Rust application. standpoint is a demo of an information extraction approach implemented as part of my honours project. I have implemented a dependency graph query tool as part of this approach; the application’s Rust component.

item.title: 2016 Macbook for software development: First Impressions
item.description: I had a little trouble with my 2012 rMBP and chose an m7 Retina Macbook as a replacement - after reading positive comments about the performance.

item.title: Getting a full refund for a faulty Macbook under UK consumer law
item.description: Below I describe the process of making a UK consumer law claim for a faulty Apple laptop. This write-up represents almost 3 months of intermittent work, 10’s of hours of phone calls and various special trips to Apple outlets.

item.title: Querying dependency graphs with Cypher and Neo4j
item.description: As part of my honours project I need to query dependency graphs. A dependency graph is a directed graph where edges represent grammatical relations and nodes are tokens.

item.title: serializer turns 1
item.description: It’s been almost a year since I started work on serializer.io, my newsreader side project. Before putting serializer together I’d had trouble finding a solution for reading news across multiple devices in a way that made sense.

item.title: Heroku Security Paper
item.description: At the end of 2015 I wrote a risk analysis of the Heroku PaaS. I learned a great deal about stack at Heroku and like to think the paper sums the workings up well.

item.title: Query corruption paper
item.description: At the end of last term I wrote a paper titled The effect of query length and search engine identity on computerised spelling correction of corrupted queries.

item.title: Deploying Go as a binary on Heroku
item.description: Here are the steps to deploy a “Hello World” Go app on Heroku as a binary - rather than the method outlined in their tutorial which uses GoDeps.

item.title: Running out of letters - A natbib journey
item.description: I wrote a risk assessment of the Heroku platform in Latex this term. It was my first large report using Latex, I ran into the following error and it look me a long time to figure out.

item.title: Heroku Outage Analysis
item.description: I’m in the process of writing a security report on Heroku. I was interested to know the number of times that attacks on the service caused downtime.

item.title: Summer at Unboxed - Round Two
item.description: Just over a week ago I completed my second summer internship at Unboxed (here’s my blog post from last year’s internship). I had the opportunity to work on an assortment of projects allowing me to experience a wide range of new tools and technologies.

item.title: Tutoring Codebar
item.description: While in London I’ve been lucky enough to attend 20 or so codebar events - over two summer internships. codebar is a weekly mentoring initiative with the goal of improving diversity in technology - for those who didn’t know.

item.title: Building and 'shipping' my side project
item.description: I started lurking on Hacker News and Product Hunt at the beginning of the year. The motivation for building serializer came from an approaching assignment deadline, rather than cutting out news I thought I’d make following it more manageable.

item.title: Enter: serializer.io
item.description: I’ve tried time and time again to make following tech news work for me. It seems to be an inordinately tough problem (for me) to solve (for myself).

item.title: I read a book
item.description: I recently finished reading Masters of Doom by David Kushner and thought I’d write a short response. It’s the first book I’ve read from start to finish since I was a child.

item.title: Digesting News with Twitter and IFTTT
item.description: I’ve been trying to cut down on the time I spend reading news for a long time, I even built my own Ruby news aggregator and summariser.

item.title: Unboxed
item.description: This summer, July through September, I completed a summer internship at Unboxed Consulting - a Rails Consultancy in London. I had a really incredible time and was lucky enough to be invited back.

item.title: I Built a Gaming PC
item.description: I thought, seeing as the exams are over and I haven’t posted in a very long time, that I’d put something new up. For a time last year I thought I’d grown out of video games, it seems this is not the case!

item.title: Vend POS & replacing desktop apps
item.description: I’ve spent most of the week (a series of 12 hour days) working with a web application called vend. It’s a program of my own selection and I was keen to get it working in the small business before I go back to university.

item.title: My IT Technician's Tools of the Trade
item.description: Programs that help lighten the load: Acronis TrueImage Plus Pack A common request at the shop is: “I want a new computer exactly like my old computer - only faster”.

item.title: Getting another perspective on IT
item.description: Two weeks ago I started working for a local IT business as a Technician, here’s what I’ve learnt. People are really troubled by their computers, I would go as far to say the older generation are, on average, scared of them.

item.title: Say no to lucky-dip level-ups
item.description: Lately I’ve been playing quite a bit of Mass Effect 3, namely the multiplayer. It’s been good fun and I’ve gotten a lot more into it than I did last time - I’ve enjoyed taking on the more difficult levels with friends.

item.title: 1 year down
item.description: My first year at university came to an end yesterday at 11:30 when I finished my ‘Web Technology’ exam. It’s been a fast few months but in that time I feel I’ve learnt enough to have an opinion on the university way.

item.title: Personal Analytics
item.description: I like recording things. Spending so much time online there is a vast amount of activity for me to log - I thought I’d have a go, in the future it might be quite interesting.

item.title: Full-on Typos
item.description: While I send the majority of emails and communication by typing out messages on a Qwerty keyboard I’m sending more and more from my phone by the week.

item.title: Gamification for Good
item.description: Gamification is a new word for me, even while the concept isn’t. Gamification is the process of implementing a social system that borrows elements from video games.

item.title: My problems with online tests
item.description: Online assessments are have become a big part of life since my move to university last year. They’re typically in the form of a web based questionnaire that are accessible via the university student portal.

item.title: Keymonk and Swype
item.description: Keymonk was really great and it felt like a truly innovative product. A few weeks ago I read this and decided it was time for a change once again.

item.title: Remove Dupes from the 'Open With' Menu
item.description: A problem that I’ve had since upgrading to 10.8 Mountain Lion has been with the Open With menu. I find that over time there is a build up of duplicates.

item.title: Umano
item.description: I recently downloaded Umano. It’s an app that gives you access to spoken news on your mobile device. I get most of my news via twitter these days, and while I’m quite happy with that system it’s sometimes nicer to get a little more depth.

item.title: The BBC doesn't understand the Internet - again
item.description: I about a week ago I read a an article on by BBC on Script Kiddies cheating Microtransation systems in games. I found the story annoying for a number of reasons.

item.title: Bungie & Destiny
item.description: At the weekend Bungie officially revealed Destiny - their next IP. While some concepts and details were leaked and highly speculated a more concrete story came on Sunday.

item.title: Instagram - First Impressions
item.description: I mentioned a few posts back that I was going to try and get back into taking some photos again - mainly just a a little log of where I’ve been.

item.title: Learning programming through websense
item.description: I’ll first describe how things worked at Dingwall Academy, my secondary school. There was a proxy server that all web traffic went through - it ran Websense.

item.title: Automatic brightness adjustment doesn't work yet
item.description: Devices are getting smarter and this helps us most of the time. However, My phone and laptop both have a disabled setting in common: Automatically Adjust Brightness.

item.title: Where should I post photos
item.description: I used to take quite a few photos - digital photography and Photoshop were really what got me into computers in the first place. I did have a go at submitting to istockphoto with a few of my better ones.

item.title: Thinking about Branch.com & Discourse.org
item.description: The topic of online discussion interests me. Talk to who you want, about what interests you and in a way that you like. While I think there are probably enough places to take part in the discussion I think we need at least one more :method of structuring that conversation.

item.title: Terminal-at-Folder
item.description: This little adjustment has probably saved me hours over the past few months and is a must for any programmer. Open_ System Preferences._ Open the Keyboard preference pane.

item.title: Getting stuck & self-teaching Rails
item.description: I’ve been working quite a bit with Rails recently and have gotten well and truly stuck. I finally gave in after about 5 hours yesterday and posted here, on stackoverflow.

item.title: Autocompletion as a tool for learning
item.description: This time last year I was in the process of getting in to XNA with C# on PC, it was how I spent my spare time back then.

item.title: Passing keywords to search engine results
item.description: I’m quite interested in an app called Summly, what originally interested me was the coverage on BBC. I guess I was surprised by his age. In an interview he talks about how he came up with the idea, it seems the idea was, originally, merely a search enhancement I think Summly is great, however the problem described in search remains unsolved.

item.title: IFTTT: Trigger Happy
item.description: This is the first review I’ve done on here for quite a while - here’s my take on IFTTT. IFTTT is an online automation service that brings together many online applications.

item.title: Notification Duplication
item.description: This is again a suggested feature for mobile phones. It’s not likely to save the same number of lives as yesterdays but it would be a nice feature all the same.

item.title: Authentication at Aberdeen University
item.description: Now that I’m back at university after the Christmas break and starting the second term I’m reminded of the incredible number of different systems (and log ins) I have to use.

item.title: Start of a Study
item.description: Before taking up my degree I spent a great deal of time trying to researching the value of a CS degree. I asked family members in the industry and spent a great deal of time online.

item.title: The Genre Games
item.description: At the same time as thinking that I’m slowly growing out of video games I remain utterly fascinated by the by the universe of my favourite series: Halo.

item.title: Why I don't like writing code in exams
item.description: As part of an upcoming exam I’ve got to write sections of code in the language we were taught. We’ve had to do this kind of thing before, at school, and I’ve been fine with it.

item.title: Some benchmarking tools
item.description: I’ve really enjoyed building computers. I like how, while it’s reasonably simple, you still get a feel that it’s somehow your own creation. Once you’ve checked for 10 fingers and toes you though want to push it a little more, make it work.

item.title: 'Sharing' as Feature
item.description: I’ve noticed a growing trend in the use of ‘share’ functions across platforms. It’s an interesting concept with great variation in it’s implementation. I’ll discuss the differences in sharing on Android, OSX and Windows 8.

item.title: Where? But to the web!
item.description: When you’re learning to program the variety can be very distracting, it’s hard to choose what to program with when there isn’t any real project. It’s just you and some spare time.

item.title: Equivocating Excellence
item.description: I’m mainly writing this for some friends over at Enemies Everywhere (update: site is no more), It’s a gaming blog and I offered to do a guest post.

item.title: Payment Without Trial
item.description: I’m a critic of app stores, I think they’ve got a long way to go before they become a good thing. They are in danger of becoming all that the consumer expects from a software distribution system, I worry there will be no incentive for content providers to build on the experience.

item.title: A positive experience with Sublime Text's support
item.description: The problem of how to enforce licensing is a big one and one that certainly deserves our attention. Many are trying new methods to license their products.

item.title: Remembering to take breaks
item.description: Recently I’ve had to put in some really long shifts at the computer to get some coursework done. It’s done now but at its peak I was spending up-to 10 hours a day sitting at the computer.

item.title: Frozen Synapse [Review]
item.description: One of the games I like to play is called Frozen Synapse. It’s a turn based strategy game that lends it’s self nicely to competitive play.

item.title: Where online MCQ tests fall short
item.description: At school, and now university, it seems trendy to have lower level assessments sat via computer - students like it for the instant results and teachers love the absence of any real marking.

item.title: The underrated iPod Shuffle
item.description: The subtle iPod Shuffle often gets overlooked, and rarely spends time in the spotlight. This is because it has, as a class of device, truly fulfilled it’s purpose as the simplest music player.

item.title: The various shortcomings of 'App Stores'
item.description: Apps Store have changed the face of the software market. They serve up content cheaply and consistently. While the content they provide may be better than ever, the stores themselves just aren’t up to scratch.

item.title: The problem with speaking to my phone
item.description: Computer dictation is something I’ve spent a much time trying out. Sadly, it’s been a let down but not due to poor accuracy. Things are fine when it’s only you for miles around, alone and productive.

item.title: Skeuomorphic Apps and Backwards Compatibility
item.description: The ‘app’ software methodology has been a success in the mobile world - and it’s trivially, tiny transactions have certainly made it very profitable. I can’t fault it, it has simplified user interaction for better and for always.

item.title: My first computer
item.description: We had a computer when I was very young - I can hardly remember - it broke and was never replaced. When you’re that age you don’t think anything of it - just get on with life, forget about it the next day.

item.title: Coderunner
item.description: There are some great apps out there that really don’t get enough recognition - CodeRunner is my personal favourite of that description. We’ve all used the command line to run code, we’ve also used a full blown IDE - but CodeRunner is something special.

item.title: Coequal Contestants
item.description: I can’t understand why we all go back to video games. Every time we play it’s ‘the last time’ yet somehow we keep coming back for another dose of disgruntlement and discontent.

item.title: Prologue
item.description: I’ve always liked the idea of keeping a diary, incrementally creating something worthwhile to look back on. This is hopefully the start of something like that.
